articles.headline: A Nearly Invisible Oil Spill Threatens Some of Asia’s Richest Fisheries
articles.snippet: Caused by a fiery collision in the East China Sea, the spill has created an environmental disaster that has tested China’s ability to lead.
articles.abstract: Caused by a fiery collision in the East China Sea, the spill has created an environmental disaster that has tested China’s ability to lead.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHOUSHAN, China — A fiery collision that sank an Iranian tanker in the East China Sea a month ago has resulted in an environmental threat that experts say is unlike any before: An almost invisible type of petroleum has begun to contaminate some of the most important fishing grounds in Asia, from China to Japan and beyond.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Javier C. Hernández

articles.headline: Steven Cohen’s Investment Firm Accused of Hostility to Women
articles.snippet: A lawsuit filed by an employee of Mr. Cohen’s company, Point72, alleges that senior employees discriminate against women. The firm denies the allegations.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit filed by an employee of Mr. Cohen’s company, Point72, alleges that senior employees discriminate against women. The firm denies the allegations.
articles.lead_paragraph: A female executive at the investment firm run by Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire investor, said in a lawsuit that the company was a testosterone-fueled “boys’ club” in which men commented on women’s bodies, belittled their abilities and paid them less than their male peers.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: As China Marches Forward on A.I., the White House Is Silent
articles.snippet: Last summer, China unveiled a plan to become the world’s leader in artificial intelligence, challenging the longtime role of the United States.
articles.abstract: Last summer, China unveiled a plan to become the world’s leader in artificial intelligence, challenging the longtime role of the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In July, China unveiled a plan to become the world leader in artificial intelligence and create an industry worth $150 billion to its economy by 2030.

articles.headline: Trump’s Infrastructure Plan Puts Burden on State and Private Money
articles.snippet: The president’s $200 billion plan recasts the federal government as a minority stakeholder in the nation’s new infrastructure projects.
articles.abstract: The president’s $200 billion plan recasts the federal government as a minority stakeholder in the nation’s new infrastructure projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s $200 billion plan to rebuild America upends the criteria that have long been used to pick ambitious federal projects, putting little emphasis on how much an infrastructure proposal benefits the public and more on finding private investors and other outside sources of money.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Does a Lawsuit Now Help the Weinstein Victims?
articles.snippet: New York’s attorney general has sued the Weinstein Company, delaying a sale, to ensure that victims of abuse are compensated. Will his tactic backfire?
articles.abstract: New York’s attorney general has sued the Weinstein Company, delaying a sale, to ensure that victims of abuse are compensated. Will his tactic backfire?
articles.lead_paragraph: It seems like a noble pursuit: Eric T. Schneiderman, New York’s attorney general, filed a lawsuit over the weekend against the Weinstein Company over the “toxic” environment it created that allowed its co-founder Harvey Weinstein to harass and abuse dozens of women.

articles.headline: A Whirlwind Envelops the White House, and the Revolving Door Spins
articles.snippet: The White House turnover rate in the first year of Donald J. Trump’s presidency has been 34 percent. That’s a modern record.
articles.abstract: The White House turnover rate in the first year of Donald J. Trump’s presidency has been 34 percent. That’s a modern record.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The doors at the White House have been swinging a lot lately. A deputy chief of staff moved on. A speechwriter resigned. The associate attorney general stepped down. The chief of staff offered to quit. And that was just Friday.

articles.headline: Germans Quietly Pass an Equinox of Unity, but the Walls Remain
articles.snippet: The Berlin Wall has been down as long as it stood. One generation lived with the wall, one without it. But in many ways it is still a tale of two countries.
articles.abstract: The Berlin Wall has been down as long as it stood. One generation lived with the wall, one without it. But in many ways it is still a tale of two countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Durs Grünbein was conceived two months after the Berlin Wall was built, in the cold winter of 1961. He spent half his life behind the wall, or, as he prefers to put it: “I spent one life as a hostage and another life free.”

articles.headline: Meth, the Forgotten Killer, Is Back. And It’s Everywhere.
articles.snippet: The fight against methamphetamines was successful, but only to a point. In some states it’s now the leading cause of drug-related deaths.
articles.abstract: The fight against methamphetamines was successful, but only to a point. In some states it’s now the leading cause of drug-related deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — They huddled against the biting wind, pacing from one corner to another hoping to score heroin or pills. But a different drug was far more likely to be on offer outside the train station downtown, where homeless drug users live in tents pitched on the sidewalk.

articles.headline: Big Profits Drove a Stock Boom. Did the Economy Pay a Price?
articles.snippet: Companies free of competitive pressures, with the power to set prices largely at will, pad the bottom line at the expense of customers and workers.
articles.abstract: Companies free of competitive pressures, with the power to set prices largely at will, pad the bottom line at the expense of customers and workers.

articles.headline: Russia Sees Midterm Elections as Chance to Sow Fresh Discord, Intelligence Chiefs Warn
articles.snippet: As the midterm elections approach, Russia is likely to throw more propaganda at Americans in an effort to deepen political divisions, American intelligence chiefs said.
articles.abstract: As the midterm elections approach, Russia is likely to throw more propaganda at Americans in an effort to deepen political divisions, American intelligence chiefs said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia is already meddling in the midterm elections this year, the top American intelligence officials said on Tuesday, warning that Moscow is using a digital strategy to worsen the country’s political and social divisions.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg, Charlie Savage and Michael Wines
